sections.title: Cardiac Arrest Drugs
sections.content: ADRENALINE (Epinephrine): Indication: Cardiac arrest (all rhythms), anaphylaxis, severe bronchospasm, shock. Cardiac arrest: 1 mg IV/IO every 3-5 min. Anaphylaxis: 0.5 mg IM (1:1000). Pediatric arrest: 10 mcg/kg (0.01 mg/kg) IV/IO. Pediatric anaphylaxis: 10 mcg/kg IM. Infusion: 0.05-0.5 mcg/kg/min. AMIODARONE: Indication: VF/pulseless VT (arrest), stable VT, AF rate control. Arrest: 300 mg IV bolus (after 3rd shock), 150 mg IV (after 5th shock). Stable arrhythmia: 300 mg IV over 20-60 min infusion, then 900 mg/24 hours. Pediatric arrest: 5 mg/kg IV bolus. ATROPINE: Indication: Symptomatic bradycardia, organophosphate poisoning. Bradycardia: 0.5 mg IV, repeat every 3-5 min (max 3 mg). Organophosphate: 2-4 mg IV, double every 5-10 min until secretions dry. Pediatric: 0.02 mg/kg IV (min 0.1 mg). MAGNESIUM SULFATE: Torsades de Pointes: 2 g (8 mmol) IV over 10-15 min. Severe asthma: 2 g IV over 20 min. Eclampsia: 4-6 g IV over 15-20 min loading + 1-2 g/hour infusion. Pediatric: 25-50 mg/kg IV (max 2 g).

sections.title: Cardiovascular Drugs
sections.content: ASPIRIN: ACS: 300 mg chewed (non-enteric coated). Maintenance: 75-100 mg/day. TICAGRELOR: ACS loading: 180 mg oral. Maintenance: 90 mg twice daily. CLOPIDOGREL: ACS loading: 300-600 mg oral. Maintenance: 75 mg/day. PRASUGREL: ACS loading: 60 mg oral. Maintenance: 10 mg/day. NITROGLYCERIN: Angina/ACS: 0.4 mg SL, up to 3 doses every 5 min. Infusion: 5-200 mcg/min IV. Contraindicated: SBP <90, right ventricular MI, PDE5 inhibitor use. HEPARIN (UFH): ACS+PCI: 70-100 U/kg IV bolus. DVT/PE: 80 U/kg IV bolus + 18 U/kg/hour infusion. ENOXAPARIN: ACS: 1 mg/kg SC twice daily. DVT/PE: 1.5 mg/kg SC once daily or 1 mg/kg SC twice daily. With fibrinolytic: <75y 30 mg IV + 1 mg/kg SC; ≥75y 0.75 mg/kg SC. ADENOSINE: SVT: 6 mg rapid IV bolus + flush, if no response 12 mg, repeat 12 mg if needed. Pediatric: 0.1 mg/kg (max 6 mg), then 0.2 mg/kg (max 12 mg). NORADRENALINE: Septic shock/vasodilatory shock: 0.05-1 mcg/kg/min IV infusion. DOBUTAMINE: Cardiogenic shock/low cardiac output: 2.5-20 mcg/kg/min IV infusion.

sections.title: Respiratory Drugs
sections.content: SALBUTAMOL: Asthma/bronchospasm — Nebulization: 5 mg (1 mL 0.5% + 3 mL NS) via nebulizer over 5-15 min, repeat every 15-20 min if needed. Continuous nebulization in severe attacks. MDI (with spacer): 4-8 puffs (100 mcg/puff), every 15-20 min. IV: 250 mcg slow IV (refractory bronchospasm). Pediatric: Nebulization 2.5-5 mg, MDI 2-4 puffs. IPRATROPIUM BROMIDE: Severe asthma — Nebulization: 0.5 mg, combined with salbutamol, 3 doses every 20 min in the first hour. Pediatric: 0.25 mg nebulization. METHYLPREDNISOLONE: Severe asthma: 40-125 mg IV. Anaphylaxis: 1-2 mg/kg IV. COPD exacerbation: 40 mg IV/oral. Pediatric: 1-2 mg/kg IV (max 60 mg). HYDROCORTISONE: Anaphylaxis: 200 mg IV. Adrenal crisis: 100 mg IV bolus. Pediatric: 4 mg/kg IV. DEXAMETHASONE: Croup: 0.15-0.6 mg/kg oral/IM (max 10 mg). Bacterial meningitis (adjunctive): 0.15 mg/kg IV every 6 hours.

sections.title: Analgesia and Sedation Drugs
sections.content: MORPHINE: Pain: 2-4 mg IV titration (every 5 min until effective). ACS: 2-4 mg IV. Pulmonary edema: 2-4 mg IV slow. Pediatric: 0.1-0.2 mg/kg IV. Caution: Respiratory depression, hypotension. Antidote: Naloxone. FENTANYL: Pain: 25-100 mcg IV (1-2 mcg/kg). Intranasal: 1.5-2 mcg/kg (if no IV access). Pediatric: 1-2 mcg/kg IV/IN. KETAMINE: Procedural sedation: 1-2 mg/kg IV or 4-5 mg/kg IM. Analgesia (subdissociative): 0.1-0.3 mg/kg IV. Pediatric: 1-2 mg/kg IV, 4-5 mg/kg IM. PARACETAMOL: Oral: 1 g (15 mg/kg), max 4 g/day. IV: 1 g (15 mg/kg) over 15 min infusion. Pediatric: 15 mg/kg oral/rectal/IV. MIDAZOLAM: Sedation: 1-2.5 mg IV titration. Seizure: 10 mg IM/IN (adult), 0.2 mg/kg IN/IM (pediatric). Antidote: Flumazenil. DIAZEPAM: Seizure: 5-10 mg IV slow (2 mg/min). Rectal: 10-20 mg. Pediatric: 0.3-0.5 mg/kg IV, 0.5 mg/kg rectal.

sections.title: Antidotes and Specific Treatment Drugs
sections.content: NALOXONE: Opioid poisoning: 0.4-2 mg IV/IM/SC/IN, repeat in 2-3 min if no response (max 10 mg). IN: 4 mg (with MAD). Pediatric: 0.1 mg/kg IV/IM. Infusion: 0.4-2 mg/hour (for long-acting opioids). FLUMAZENIL: Benzodiazepine poisoning: 0.2 mg IV over 30 sec, then 0.3 mg followed by 0.5 mg doses if needed (max 3 mg). Caution: Seizure risk in chronic benzodiazepine users. N-ACETYLCYSTEINE (NAC): Paracetamol poisoning — IV protocol: 150 mg/kg over 1 hour + 50 mg/kg over 4 hours + 100 mg/kg over 16 hours. CALCIUM GLUCONATE (10%): Hyperkalemia: 10-30 mL IV over 2-5 min. HF poisoning: Topical gel + IV. Ca-channel blocker OD: 30-60 mL IV. Pediatric: 0.5 mL/kg IV. SODIUM BICARBONATE (8.4%): TCA poisoning (wide QRS): 1-2 mEq/kg IV bolus. Metabolic acidosis: 1 mEq/kg IV. Hyperkalemia: 50 mEq IV. Crush syndrome: Urine alkalinization. TRANEXAMIC ACID: Traumatic hemorrhage: 1 g IV over 10 min + 1 g over 8 hours infusion (give within first 3 hours). Postpartum hemorrhage: 1 g IV over 10 min. GLUCAGON: Beta-blocker poisoning: 5-10 mg IV bolus + 1-5 mg/hour infusion. Hypoglycemia (if IM insulin unavailable): 1 mg IM/SC. HYDROXOCOBALAMIN: Cyanide poisoning: 5 g IV over 15 min (adult), 70 mg/kg (pediatric).

sections.title: Fluid and Electrolyte Therapy
sections.content: 0.9% NaCl (Isotonic Saline): Volume replacement: 250-1000 mL IV bolus. Crush syndrome: 1-1.5 L/hour. Pediatric bolus: 20 mL/kg. RINGER'S LACTATE: Trauma fluid replacement: 1-2 L IV bolus. Burns (Parkland): 4 mL x kg x %TBSA/24 hours. 10% DEXTROSE: Hypoglycemia: 250 mL IV (adult), 5 mL/kg IV (pediatric). 50% DEXTROSE: Hypoglycemia (concentrated): 50 mL IV (25 g). Caution: Tissue necrosis if extravasated. 3% HYPERTONIC SALINE: Severe hyponatremia (seizures): 150 mL IV over 20 min, max 3 doses. Severe raised ICP: 2-5 mL/kg IV over 10-20 min. MANNITOL (20%): Raised ICP: 0.25-1 g/kg IV over 15-20 min. Crush syndrome: 1-2 g/kg IV. POTASSIUM CHLORIDE: Hypokalemia: 10-20 mEq/hour IV (max 40 mEq/hour with monitoring). Never IV push! REGULAR INSULIN: Hyperkalemia: 10 U IV + 50 mL 50% Dextrose. DKA: 0.1 U/kg/hour IV infusion.

sections.title: Other Emergency Drugs
sections.content: TENECTEPLASE: STEMI fibrinolytic: <60 kg: 30 mg, 60-69 kg: 35 mg, 70-79 kg: 40 mg, 80-89 kg: 45 mg, ≥90 kg: 50 mg IV bolus. OXYTOCIN: Postpartum hemorrhage: 5-10 U IM or 5 U slow IV, then 10-40 U/500 mL infusion. METOCLOPRAMIDE: Nausea/vomiting: 10 mg IV/IM. Pediatric: 0.1-0.15 mg/kg IV (max 10 mg). ONDANSETRON: Nausea/vomiting: 4-8 mg IV slow. Pediatric: 0.1-0.15 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg). DIPHENHYDRAMINE: Allergic reaction: 25-50 mg IV/IM. Pediatric: 1 mg/kg IV/IM (max 50 mg). PHENIRAMINE MALEATE: Allergic reaction: 45.5 mg IM/IV slow. RANITIDINE: Anaphylaxis (H2 blocker): 50 mg IV slow (20 min infusion). FUROSEMIDE: Acute pulmonary edema: 20-80 mg IV slow (1-2 min). Pediatric: 0.5-1 mg/kg IV. PRALIDOXIME: Organophosphate poisoning: 1-2 g IV over 15-30 min. Pediatric: 25-50 mg/kg IV. LEVETIRACETAM: Status epilepticus (2nd line): 60 mg/kg IV over 10 min (max 4500 mg). PHENYTOIN: Status epilepticus (2nd line): 20 mg/kg IV max 50 mg/min (with cardiac monitor). VALPROIC ACID: Status epilepticus (2nd line): 40 mg/kg IV over 10 min (max 3000 mg).

sections.title: Important Warnings and General Principles
sections.content: 1) ALL DOSES MUST BE WEIGHT-BASED — especially in pediatric and elderly patients. 2) When administering IV drugs, always pay attention to dilution and infusion rate. 3) DRUG ALLERGY: Always ask before administering any drug. 4) IN PREGNANCY: Avoid Category D and X drugs (methotrexate, warfarin, phenytoin, etc.). Safe in pregnancy: Paracetamol, methylprednisolone, magnesium sulfate, labetalol. 5) IN RENAL FAILURE: Drugs requiring dose adjustment: enoxaparin, digoxin, aminoglycosides, morphine. 6) IN HEPATIC FAILURE: Paracetamol max 2 g/day, reduce morphine dose, valproic acid contraindicated. 7) IN ELDERLY: Halve the starting dose, titrate slowly ('start low, go slow'). 8) INFUSION PUMP: Vasoactive agents (noradrenaline, adrenaline, dobutamine) and insulin must always be given via infusion pump. 9) EXTRAVASATION: Noradrenaline, calcium, 50% dextrose, phenytoin — extravasation causes tissue necrosis. 10) THIS TABLE IS A REFERENCE — clinical decisions must always be based on the individual patient's condition.
